call_title: Completeness of Ergo | Alex Chepurnoy | ErgoHack 9

topics.title: Introduction and Ergo Protocol Completeness Overview
topics.summary: Alexander Chepurnoy introduces himself as co-developer of Ergo Protocol since 2016 and presents his reflections on protocol completeness on the 5th Ergoversary. He outlines the talk's focus on protocol research priorities and core development roadmap.

topics.title: Cryptocurrency Requirements and Blockchain Trilemma
topics.summary: Discussion of fundamental cryptocurrency requirements including security, decentralization, and performance. Introduces the blockchain trilemma concept where only two of three aspects (scalability, security, decentralization) can be optimized simultaneously.

topics.title: Performance Metrics and TPS Limitations
topics.summary: Explains why TPS (Transactions Per Second) is a misleading metric for blockchain performance. Discusses how different transaction types and accounting models make simple TPS comparisons inadequate, using Binance Smart Chain as an example of high TPS with poor verifiability.

topics.title: Ergo's Pruning-Based Scalability Approach
topics.summary: Details Ergo's approach to solving the trilemma by prioritizing security and decentralization while enabling scalability through comprehensive pruning capabilities. Covers full block pruning via NippoPoWs, header pruning, stateless clients, and the storage rent mechanism that charges fees every four years.

topics.title: Protocol Completeness and Security Assessment
topics.summary: Evaluates the current completeness of the Ergo protocol, concluding that security and decentralization aspects are nearly perfect. Emphasizes that future improvements should focus on provable enhancements rather than arbitrary feature additions.

topics.title: Development Roadmap and Future Improvements
topics.summary: Outlines the development roadmap focusing on polishing pruning capabilities, optimizing transaction validation and mempool, implementing compact blocks, and potentially adding ErgoTree instructions for layer 2 support. Emphasizes that improvements can be made through soft forks and client upgrades without breaking changes.
